abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Private Irrigation
            Promotion Project for Niger are as follows: outcomes of the
            project were highly satisfactory, risk to development
            outcome was substantial, bank performance was satisfactory,
            and borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: the project's emphasis on
            cost-effective small-scale irrigation with full
            participation of the private sector remains valid and highly
            relevant for Niger. The project design and the technologies
            could be an important example for other countries facing
            much less severe constraints. Irrigation investments under
            the project had an average cost of approximately US$2,000
            per hectare. These investments can bring measurable
            improvements in farmers' welfare and achieve high
            economic rates of return, possibly above 20 percent. The
            project shows that additional responsibilities are created
            for the private sector when it manages projects that are
            highly visible and politically charged. Transparency in
            financial management and procurement is essential.
            Monitoring and evaluation greatly helped to inform decision-making.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Private Irrigation
            Promotion Project is to increase production and
            profitability of high-value, irrigated crops by private,
            smallholder farmers with simple, low-cost technologies.
            There are four main project components. The first component
            has two sub-components: The first concerns participatory
            research aimed at developing and testing new technologies
            with farmer participation to increase irrigated production
            and add value. The second involves advisory services, aimed
            at ensuring that farmers are provided relevant and effective
            advice on production and marketing on a regular and timely
            basis, and aimed at disseminating technologies proved
            effective in the pilot phase of the project. The second
            component comprises three elements: The first supports the
            Nigerien Association for the Promotion of Private Irrigation
            (ANPIP) in its acquiring increasing autonomy,
            sustainability, and accountability to its members, and also
            provides support to producers' organizations. The
            second subcomponent supports the government's efforts
            in promoting private irrigation. The third subcomponent is a
            pilot, testing private management of selected offices for
            irrigated perimeters (ONAHA) to develop models enabling the
            government to disengage itself from being directly involved
            in these schemes. The third component finances an irrigation
            investment fund and microfinance institutions. The fourth
            component puts in place an action plan aimed at mitigating
            environmental risks.

repnme.cdata!:
Niger - Private Irrigation Promotion
            Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This environmental assessment discusses
            at the same time environmental risks and mitigations covered
            in the Pilot Private Irrigation Promotion Project (see
            report no. 13939 SAR) as well as those examined in the
            expanded Private Irrigation Promotion Project. Only the
            usage of agrochemicals constitutes a major negative
            environmental impact, the impact on the health of farm
            families causing the principal concern. Other significant
            environmental issues for small-scale irrigation is the
            possibility for excessive water extraction from the
            construction of hand-held pumps, the cultivation of new land
            parcels (accompanied by deforestation and the soil
            deterioration), the draw-down of the water table, and the
            drainage of sediment and runoff and their concomitant effect
            on water quality. Measures to mitigate these negative
            impacts include: Developing an environmental assessment of
            each site and systematically monitoring it ; elaborating and
            incorporating environmental clauses in all legal documents
            and contracts relative to this project; putting in place a
            matching grant system enabling land valuation and
            environmental preservation; and researching technological
            options for aquifer use. Finally, an autonomous
            nongovernmental organization, the Nigerienne Association for
            Promoting Private Irrigation (ANPIP), will be charged with
            managing the project's environmental aspects.
